cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerC: Shoes worn thinly
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.answerC: Feeling hungry
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.answerC: One third
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: Texting while driving is worrisome:
questions.answerA: Because it creates both mental and physical distractions.
questions.answerB: Because a message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: Because the texts may be more interesting than the task of driving.
questions.answerD: Because it is less efficient than a phone call.
questions.explanation: When driving, texting is a particularly dangerous distraction because it distracts a driver both mentally and physically.

questions.question: Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck:
questions.answerA: Is a good way for inexperienced drivers to gain experience.
questions.answerC: Is illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.answerC: Stay in control when stopping.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together on all axles.
questions.answerB: Should be used together, but only on the rear axle.
questions.answerC: Should not be used together.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, ensure that radial and bias-ply tires are not being used together.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks before an approaching train reaches the crossing.
questions.explanation: You should approach every railroad crossing with the expectation that a train is coming. Do not rely on signals or your hearing to reliably tell you if a train is present. Always slow down when approaching a crossing. Never try to race a train.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Prevent cargo from shifting in transit.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.answerD: Prevent cargo from being unloaded easily.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from sliding in transit.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: Good drivers consistently look ____ seconds ahead of their vehicles.
questions.explanation: Most good drivers consistently look down the road 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Watching ahead of your vehicle will allow you to react to upcoming hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of distraction?
questions.answerC: Obtuse
questions.explanation: Distractions that can affect safe driving can be classified as physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as talking with passenger), or both (such as talking on a hand-held phone).

questions.question: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerC: Push against the inside of the drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: Do not use the parking brake when parking if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.answerD: There is water on the ground.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerC: Excessive use of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they can become too hot. This overheating causes them to fade, making them less effective at slowing the vehicle.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.answerC: Is required on some roads.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: What is a drawback of retarders?
questions.answerA: They may not be permitted everywhere.
questions.answerB: They can help to slow a vehicle.
questions.answerC: They cannot be turned off.
questions.explanation: A retarder is a device that helps to slow a vehicle, reducing the need for a driver to use the brakes. However, these devices can be noisy and are not permitted everywhere.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate especially slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To keep from accelerating faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under slippery conditions. Using too much power in such conditions may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.answerC: Increase.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase. When approaching a downgrade, choose to travel at a speed that will be safe for the size and weight of your vehicle.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), when the vehicle is started:
questions.answerB: The ABS indicator light should turn on, then quickly shut off.
questions.answerC: The steering wheel will not move until the air tanks are full.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine of a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), the indicator light should come on and then turn off. If the light stays on, something is wrong with the ABS.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be helpful to see a wider area.
questions.answerD: Are illegal to be used in most states.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only happens when drivers are physically doing something, like using a cell phone.
questions.answerC: Can occur due to mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Mental distractions can be just as dangerous as physical ones. It is possible for a person to look right at a hazard on the road but fail to notice it because their thoughts are occupied by something else.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: When trying to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than stopping.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes without looking.
questions.answerD: You should drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the most effective response to a hazard. You can usually turn out of the path of a hazard more quickly than you can come to a complete stop. However, swerving is not without its hazards, as it may result in a rollover in a vehicle that is either top-heavy or pulling multiple trailers.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: If a five-foot-long item is placed on a flatbed trailer, it must be secured by at least:
questions.answerC: Three tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo that is required to be tied down should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo length. However, at least two tie-downs should be used no matter how small the cargo is.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.answerC: Be checked regularly.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerC: Tires manufactured by different makers
questions.explanation: Be sure to thoroughly inspect your tires before a trip. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut, cracked, or otherwise damaged in any way.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: The minimum size of placards identifying hazardous materials is:
questions.answerC: Nine and three-quarter inches.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be at least 10 and three-quarter inches square.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerC: GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: Why should rental trucks be approached with caution?
questions.answerA: It is a rental vehicle, so it likely isn’t insured.
questions.answerB: Drivers are usually worried about their cargo.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not be familiar with the limited views to the sides and rear.
questions.answerD: They do not respond to the driver as well as other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when driving near rental trucks because the people driving them may not be used to operating vehicles with limited views to the sides and rear. Drivers who cannot see others on the roadway are hazardous.

questions.question: When checking power steering hoses during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Extra hose pieces available for repairs.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection on a vehicle with power steering, be sure to check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: A vehicle that is smaller than your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Will usually be able to stop faster than your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Will usually take more time to stop than your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will take about the same amount of time to stop as your vehicle.
questions.explanation: In general, a smaller vehicle will be able to come to a complete stop faster than a larger vehicle. Keep this in mind when determining your following distance.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: When making a left turn where there are two available turn lanes, a driver should begin the turn in the rightmost lane because:
questions.answerA: It will be easier for the driver to keep track of turning vehicles on their left than on their right.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be able to turn more quickly.
questions.answerC: Other vehicles will get out of the turning vehicle's way.
questions.explanation: If making a left turn where there is more than one available turn lane, you should always choose to begin your turn in the rightmost lane. Large vehicles often have to swing right to make left turns. Because of this, it is safer for you to have other left-turning traffic to your left instead of to your right. This will allow you to have the best possible view of other turning vehicles and will lower the risk of your vehicle colliding with them.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of a potentially drunk driver?
questions.answerA: They are staying in their traffic lane.
questions.answerB: They are driving a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: They are stopping without a reason.
questions.answerD: They have alcohol-related bumper stickers on their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs that a driver may be impaired include that they are having trouble staying in their lane, they are having trouble maintaining an appropriate driving speed, or they are stopping without a clear reason.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerC: The engine should be running.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: If someone pulls out in front of you and you cannot stop to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Just hit the other vehicle since it will be the other driver's fault.
questions.answerB: Swerve to avoid the other car.
questions.answerC: Put your vehicle in reverse.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle pulls out in front of you, it is appropriate to brake as long as there is room for your vehicle to stop while you are using the appropriate braking technique. However, if you do not have room to stop, swerving may be a safer response.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.answerC: Be checked regularly.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: When carrying a wide load, you should:
questions.answerB: Obtain special permits and follow special rules.
questions.answerC: Honk at other drivers to get them to move from the lane closest to you.
questions.explanation: Loads that are over-length, over-width, and/or overweight may require special permits. Drivers of such loads may be subject to special restrictions, such as only being permitted to drive at certain times.

questions.question: When should mirror adjustments be made?
questions.answerC: When a vehicle is stopped at a traffic signal
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of each trip. Any attached trailer should be straight while mirrors are being adjusted.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: When stopped on the side of the road, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: One quarter mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: The tire load:
questions.answerA: Can be exceeded in cooler conditions.
questions.answerB: Is the maximum safe weight a tire can carry at a given pressure.
questions.answerC: Must be written in the shipping papers.
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight a tire can safely carry at a given pressure. This rating is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in work zones?
questions.answerC: Drivers driving too slowly
questions.explanation: Speeding traffic is the main cause of death and injury in work zones. Drive with special caution when traveling near road workers.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: If using the spring brakes while hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes will activate in a vehicle with air brakes if the pressure in the air system becomes too low. A heavily loaded vehicle will take a long time to stop when using only the spring brakes because the spring brakes do not work on all axles.

questions.question: About how many drinks does it take for a 200-pound person to reach a 0.02 percent blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairment begins long before the legal limit is reached. A 200-pound person will reach a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.02 percent after a single drink.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.answerC: Eight to nine
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need seven to eight hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: On a wet road, you should reduce your speed:
questions.answerC: By about one-quarter.
questions.explanation: You should reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill, you can reduce the amount of required braking by:
questions.answerC: Switching into neutral.
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, decelerate and shift down into a gear that will allow you to control your vehicle without braking too hard. Using too much brake when driving downhill can cause the brakes to overheat, reducing the braking power.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, your best hope to stop is:
questions.answerC: Stay on the road.
questions.answerD: Hitting a slower vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, your best option is to use an escape ramp. If no escape ramp is available, it is a good idea to look for a different escape route, such as a side road or open field.

questions.question: A sign that your vehicle's brakes will need repair is that the:
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.answerC: The brake pads are worn thin.
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: The maximum amount of play that is safe on a 20-inch steering wheel is:
questions.answerC: 10 inches.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel with play of more than 10 degrees may be defective. On a 20-inch wheel, this is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of the wheel.

questions.question: Once they have begun to drive after a tire on their vehicle has been changed, a driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire is wearing evenly.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the air pressure of the tire is still acceptable.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn very sharply.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerC: Push against the inside of the drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: What should be done before transporting an over-length load?
questions.answerA: Special transit permits should be acquired.
questions.answerB: Fire departments along the route should be alerted.
questions.answerC: Tolls should be paid.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits from the Department of Transportation.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.answerC: Air brakes
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerC: Must be washed.
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: If a truck's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at slow speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.answerD: The truck will lack brakes on its left side.
questions.explanation: If an ABS system fails, the vehicle will still have normal braking function. The driver should continue to drive and brake as they normally would.

questions.question: Air tanks usually hold enough compressed air:
questions.answerA: For one stop before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerB: For several stops before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerC: For a day’s worth of braking.
questions.answerD: For an unlimited number of stops.
questions.explanation: In an air braking system, the air storage tanks can usually hold enough compressed air for the brakes to be used several times.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: Why should your mirrors be adjusted to show the road behind you as well as part of your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Having only the road in the mirrors would likely make the driver carsick.
questions.answerB: Having part of the truck in the mirrors serves as a point of reference.
questions.answerC: It is illegal to have only the road in the mirrors.
questions.answerD: The driver should be able to see the reflection of surrounding vehicles on the trailer.
questions.explanation: Part of your vehicle should be visible in your mirrors so that you have a point of reference when judging how close other drivers and objects are to your vehicle.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerC: Pulling a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: To prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move, you can:
questions.answerA: Partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in second gear.
questions.answerC: Use the parking brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: To ensure that your vehicle does not roll backward when beginning to move after a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your right foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Open the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator in an air brake system:
questions.answerA: Makes the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevents ice from forming in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Lubricates parts of the braking system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an evaporator that introduces alcohol into the system. The alcohol can help prevent ice from forming within the system.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Brake normally.
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Each system has separate air tanks, hoses, and lines.
questions.answerB: The systems share air tanks, but each has its own separate hoses and lines.
questions.answerC: Each system uses the same lines and hoses.
questions.answerD: One system is the main braking system and a second system is ready to be used if the first one fails.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel use tax returns must be kept by carriers for:
questions.answerC: Three years.
questions.explanation: In general, if you operate a commercial vehicle in interstate commerce, it must be registered under the International Registration Plan (IRP) and International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA). These programs collect and distribute vehicle registration fees and fuel taxes based on what jurisdictions you drive in and for how long. Mileage and fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel tax returns must be retained by carriers for four years.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread of at least 2/32 an inch on rear tires
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; that there is at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth in grooves on other tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerC: Air brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring cargo is loaded properly?
questions.answerC: The recipient
questions.explanation: A driver is responsible for four things related to transporting cargo. They are responsible for inspecting the cargo, recognizing overloads and poorly balanced weight, ensuring that the cargo is secured without obstructing their view, and ensuring that the cargo is not obstructing access to emergency equipment.

questions.question: When carrying a sealed load, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should unseal the load to ensure safety.
questions.answerB: Should ensure the weight does not exceed weight limits.
questions.answerC: Must go through the container before driving.
questions.explanation: Though a driver cannot inspect a sealed load, they should still ensure that the load does not exceed applicable weight limits.

questions.question: Without engine oil:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will get better gas mileage.
questions.answerB: An engine can be destroyed quickly.
questions.answerC: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) won’t work properly.
questions.explanation: It is critical that an engine have sufficient oil pressure. The engine can be destroyed rapidly if run without oil.

questions.question: A cargo van carrying a light load is usually:
questions.answerA: The same height as when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerB: Taller than when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerC: Shorter than when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerD: Less stable than when carrying a heavier load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerC: Time of day.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect your vehicle's stopping distance include driving speed, the vehicle's weight, and the slipperiness of the road surface.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerC: Not drive in any lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Remove the alternator belt.
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: How can you prevent drowsiness before a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about four hours of sleep.
questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Drive alone.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: When using your mirrors, you should frequently look at your tires to:
questions.answerB: See if the tires are rolling properly.
questions.answerC: See if the tread is sufficient.
questions.answerD: Get a sense of the size of the tire in relation to other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Check your tires regularly when looking in your mirrors. This helps ensure that you will notice a tire fire, if one should happen. Tire fires may occur when a tire is under-inflated, if dual tires are touching, or if the tires are otherwise overheated.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Not apply any brake.
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerC: Drain the brake fluid.
questions.answerD: Check the windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerC: Turning on your headlights.
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: If pulled over on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other drivers.
questions.answerD: Set out items from the cab to warn motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers and place the appropriate warning signals to warn other drivers.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.answerC: Tires manufactured by different makers
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: While still below the legal limit, a driver operating a CMV with a detectable amount of alcohol in their system will:
questions.answerA: Result in an out-of-service order for two hours.
questions.answerB: Result in an out-of-service order for 10 hours.
questions.answerC: Result in an out-of-service order for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to have any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while operating a CMV but your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When steering to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use one hand to steer.
questions.answerB: Keep both hands on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to check other lanes.
questions.answerD: Speed up as you get nearer to the hazard.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid colliding with a hazard in the roadway, you should always keep both hands on the steering wheel. You must have a firm grip on the wheel to be able to turn quickly.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and tell them of the driver's behavior.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: Why are roads especially slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: Gravel often gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Tires are not usually designed to drive in rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, roads are often at their most slippery when the rain first begins to fall. Fresh rainwater mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slick film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, the engine oil pressure should come up to normal:
questions.answerC: Within three minutes.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle's engine is started, the engine's oil pressure should rise to its normal level within seconds. Do not drive a vehicle with oil pressure that is too low.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report from the previous driver:
questions.answerA: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely on the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerC: The driver should review the report.
questions.answerD: The driver should speak with the previous driver.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is equipped on a trailer but not on a tractor:
questions.answerA: The truck should not be driven because ABS needs to be on both the tractor and trailer.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: The tractor should not be used and a new tractor with ABS should be located.
questions.answerD: The tractor and trailer can still be used together.
questions.explanation: A vehicle being equipped with anti-lock brakes on only the tractor or only the trailer provides additional control during braking.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: When performing the stop/start maneuver as a part of the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Cut off other vehicles if needed to get onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Slam on the brakes to stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be asked to pull your vehicle over to the side of the road and stop as if you were going to get out and check something on your vehicle. As you prepare to make this stop, you must check traffic; activate your turn signal; decelerate smoothly with even braking, changing gears as needed; and bring your vehicle to a full stop without coasting.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerC: Staying in your lane
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: After two violations of any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use:
questions.answerA: You will need to cancel your mobile phone service.
questions.answerC: You will be required to drive 10 mph under the posted speed limit for a period of time.
questions.explanation: If you are twice convicted of violating any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use, your CDL will be disqualified. Consequences will become more severe with subsequent violations.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerA: But only if it is cold outside.
questions.answerC: Both when it is cold and hot outside.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerB: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.answerC: Freeze before other surfaces.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the road surface. You should be especially careful on bridges when temperatures are near the freezing point.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.answerC: Cut up with an axe.
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Who is responsible for cargo that has been loaded onto a truck?
questions.answerA: The person who loaded the truck
questions.answerC: The truck driver
questions.explanation: Even if they did not load or secure the cargo themselves, the driver of a vehicle is responsible for inspecting the cargo and ensuring that it is properly secured.

questions.question: A vehicle stopped at a green light may indicate that the driver:
questions.answerC: Does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good rule to follow when making a turn?
questions.answerB: Use your arms to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn off your turn signal before entering the turn to avoid confusing other drivers.
questions.explanation: Signal well in advance of a turn so drivers behind you are aware of your intentions. Keep the signal on throughout the turn and turn it off once the turn is complete.

questions.question: A liver can process about ____ per hour.
questions.answerC: Three alcoholic drinks
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the higher your blood alcohol content (BAC) will become. The liver removes alcohol from a body at a fixed rate of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.answerC: Driving downhill.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: Who may operate a vehicle that requires placards to be driven?
questions.answerB: A driver with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A driver with a minimum of 10 years of commercial driving experience
questions.answerD: Any person who thinks they can
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a HazMat endorsement to operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Air tanks usually hold enough compressed air:
questions.answerA: For one stop before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerB: For several stops before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerC: For a day’s worth of braking.
questions.answerD: For an unlimited number of stops.
questions.explanation: In an air braking system, the air storage tanks can usually hold enough compressed air for the brakes to be used several times.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When leaving a vehicle unattended, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Only set the parking brake if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: Deflate the tires by 10 percent.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.answerC: Is required on some roads.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerC: Is required on slippery surfaces.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: The passenger side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerB: The driver's side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerC: Mirrors on both sides of the vehicle should be used.
questions.explanation: Regularly check mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while driving. It is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a truck's cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When traveling down a long downgrade, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and downshifting occasionally.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using brakes.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, you should use the braking effect of your engine as the principal way of controlling your speed. Save your brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged at all speeds.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: The faster you drive:
questions.answerA: The shorter your stopping distance will be.
questions.answerB: The longer your stopping distance will be.
questions.answerC: The easier it will be to stop your vehicle.
questions.explanation: The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become. Brake accordingly.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerC: Pulling up gradually.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.answerC: To transport hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: A vehicle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for a parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If your brakes fail when traveling downhill, decide what to do as quickly as possible because:
questions.answerA: The longer you wait, the faster your vehicle will go.
questions.answerB: The longer you wait, the more vehicles will get out of your way.
questions.answerC: The longer you wait, the slower your vehicle will go.
questions.explanation: However you choose to deal with a brake failure on a downhill slope, it is important that you make your decision as quickly as possible. The longer you wait to act, the faster your vehicle will be moving, and the harder it will become to stop.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerC: One inch
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: If driving a truck that requires a CDL for operation:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You are always required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are only required to wear a seat belt when driving a tank trailer.
questions.explanation: For safety, you must wear your seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerC: Not a hazard when driving.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator is especially important:
questions.answerC: In dry weather.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerC: The brakes may be sluggish.
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.answerC: Not be used for cargo.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.answerC: Cruise control.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: What does a vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Tells the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Holds drivers accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: Drivers may be required to submit a written vehicle inspection report at the end of each day of driving. The motor carrier must repair any items in the report that affect safety and certify on the report that repairs were either made or unnecessary.

questions.question: If someone pulls out in front of you and you cannot stop to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Just hit the other vehicle since it will be the other driver's fault.
questions.answerB: Swerve to avoid the other car.
questions.answerC: Put your vehicle in reverse.
