questions.explanation: If another vehicle pulls out in front of you, it is appropriate to brake as long as there is room for your vehicle to stop while you are using the appropriate braking technique. However, if you do not have room to stop, swerving may be a safer response.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash down the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the other driver’s behavior to police.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: 15 mph
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: As temperatures begin to rise and ice on road surfaces begin to melt:
questions.answerA: It is especially safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become more slippery.
questions.answerC: Traction will increase.
questions.answerD: It will be easier to identify slippery spots.
questions.explanation: Ice that is wet because it has just begun to melt is much more slippery than ice that is not wet. Use additional caution when driving on melting ice.

questions.question: When using road speed to know when to switch gears, you should:
questions.answerA: Learn what speeds each gear is good for and shift up when necessary.
questions.answerB: Watch other vehicles and try to keep pace.
questions.answerC: Watch other trucks and shift when they shift.
questions.answerD: Use the speed limit as a guide.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: When entering traffic, a large vehicle usually needs:
questions.answerA: Less space than is needed for a car.
questions.answerB: About the same amount of space as is needed for a car.
questions.answerC: More space than is needed for a car.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle requires more space when entering or crossing traffic than a smaller vehicle. This is not only because the vehicle itself is larger, but also because it needs a longer distance to accelerate.

questions.question: When inspecting underneath your vehicle for leaking fluids, you must look for all the following, except:
questions.answerC: Grease.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before a trip, be sure to look underneath the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerC: Shoes worn thinly
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Increase the space in front of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.answerC: Tire manufacturer.
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: With some exceptions, you must have a tank endorsement to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous substances.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.answerC: Use your mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: Make a point of checking your mirrors often when making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: What should happen if the air pressure in the air brake system tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light should come on.
questions.answerB: Lights should flash on the outside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A message should appear on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On vehicles with air brakes, a low air pressure warning signal will come on if the pressure in the air tanks falls below 60 psi. On large buses, the signal may activate at 80 to 85 psi.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.answerC: Driving away from the scene
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Prevent cargo from shifting in transit.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.answerD: Prevent cargo from being unloaded easily.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from sliding in transit.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.answerC: Complete an emergency stop.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If your bus has a manual transmission, what should you never do when crossing railroad tracks?
questions.answerC: Look both ways.
questions.explanation: Do not shift gears while crossing railroad tracks. Your vehicle could stall and get stuck in the crossing.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.answerC: Near a river
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should :
questions.answerA: Always exit through the rear door.
questions.answerC: Always exit through the front door.
questions.explanation: When preparing to evacuate a school bus, the driver must quickly determine which of the bus's exits is safest for passengers to use.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The lift is fully extended.
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Monitor your gauges.
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.answerC: Stop on the sidewalk.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Point to or touch each item.
questions.answerC: Explain what you are checking and why.
questions.explanation: As a part of earning your CDL, you will have to pass an inspection test and demonstrate that your vehicle is safe for operation. During the vehicle inspection test, you will have to walk around the vehicle and point to or touch each item and explain to the examiner what you are checking and why. You will not have to crawl under the hood or under the vehicle.

questions.question: School bus stops may be changed by:
questions.answerC: The school district.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not change the location of a stop without written approval from appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When loading or unloading passengers, a school bus should be placed in ____ if there is no park shift point available.
questions.answerC: Neutral
questions.explanation: When stopping to load or unload students, a school bus should ideally be placed in park. If there is no park shift point, the bus should be placed in neutral and the parking brake should be set.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: Monitors traffic.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all waiting students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn the bus off and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask a student to keep an eye on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus for the missing student.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.answerC: Two points of contact
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake to stop.
questions.answerD: You should stop driving and wait for the ABS to work again.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help a school bus driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: If a driver cannot account for a student after the student has exited the bus, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure and leave the bus to look for the student.
questions.answerB: Assume the student has safely exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the bus to see if the student got back on.
questions.answerD: Ask another student if they've seen the student.
questions.explanation: During unloading, if a school bus driver cannot account for a student outside of the bus, they should secure the bus and check for the missing student around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.answerC: Two points of contact
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The drive shaft should:
questions.answerA: Be bent toward the passenger side.
questions.answerB: Be bent toward the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Be bent to one side or the other.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you should check that the drive shaft is not bent or cracked.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: The decision to proceed rests with each driver.
questions.answerB: The decision to proceed should be based on a control device.
questions.answerC: The decision to proceed should be based on surrounding vehicles.
questions.answerD: The decision to proceed is left to passengers in each vehicle.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.answerC: 200 feet
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.answerC: 50 feet
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: A bus driver approaching a bus stop should stop at least 10 feet away from waiting students because:
questions.answerA: The students will have to walk to the bus, making it easier to see their movements.
questions.answerC: The students may get scared of the bus coming toward them.
questions.explanation: At a stop, a school bus should be stopped with the front bumper at least 10 feet away from the students. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to keep an eye on their movements.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Back up after the students board the bus.
questions.answerC: Back up while students direct you.
questions.explanation: Backing in a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other safe way to move the vehicle. If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should wait until all students have first loaded the bus.

questions.question: What do outside crossover mirrors allow a driver to see?
questions.answerC: The right side of the bus
questions.answerD: The left side of the bus
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a school bus driver see the danger zone area directly in front of the bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: If there is a fire on a school bus, the students:
questions.answerB: Should stay on the bus but be moved to a part of the bus unaffected by the fire.
questions.answerC: Should stay in their seats.
questions.explanation: If a school bus is on fire, or if there is a threat of fire, it is mandatory for a bus driver to evacuate the students from the bus.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students load the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students load the bus before backing up.
questions.answerC: Let half of the students load the bus and then back up to meet the second half.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, do not put the bus in reverse until all students have boarded. Watch for late-comers at all times.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If a school bus stalls on a railroad track:
questions.answerA: Students should remain on the bus.
questions.answerB: Students should be evacuated to a location near the bus.
questions.answerC: Students should be evacuated and moved away from the bus.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. If the bus is struck by a train, to avoid any flying debris, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually shaped like what?
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.answerC: Radioactive.
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle’s parking brake.
questions.explanation: If loading by hand, load breakable containers of corrosive liquid one by one. Keep them facing upright. Do not drop or roll the containers.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: A placard identifying hazardous materials must be placed:
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on the front, rear, and both sides of a vehicle.

questions.question: To know which placards to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers holding the materials.
questions.answerC: The destination.
questions.explanation: To determine which hazardous materials placards to use, you must know the hazard class of the materials; the amount of hazardous materials being shipped; and the total weight of all classes of hazardous materials in the vehicle.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Remove your protective equipment.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.answerC: You can always use tunnels.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in the trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air-dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to a corrosive material must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.answerC: The use of the materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on shipping papers:
questions.answerA: An inhalation hazard placard must be used, but only if more than 100 pounds of the material are being transported.
questions.answerB: An inhalation hazard placard must be used when any amount of the material is being transported.
questions.answerC: Air masks must be provided to anyone handling the cargo.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" are on a package or its shipping paper, you must display the proper inhalation hazard placards, as well as any other necessary placards. This applies regardless of the amount of materials being carried.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerC: On private property.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerC: Other items.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you can identify the leaking cargo:
questions.answerC: By using the shipping papers.
questions.answerD: By rubbing it on your arm.
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, labels, or package locations to identify the materials involved. Do not touch the leaking materials.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerC: Open.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: The identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerC: In the Periodic Table of Elements.
questions.explanation: Information about hazardous chemicals is found in the Emergency Response Guide (ERG) provided by U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT). The ERG is indexed by the proper shipping names and identification numbers of substances.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerC: Straps.
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.answerC: A chemical suit
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Color-coded pieces of tape
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.answerC: Gases.
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.answerC: Turned on.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.question: A driver needs a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to transport hazardous materials in:
questions.answerA: A vehicle requiring a Class A license.
questions.answerB: A vehicle requiring a Class B license.
questions.answerC: A vehicle requiring a Class C license.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.answerC: Special provisions for the materials.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerC: Driver information.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerC: An axe
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: While driving, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Hidden under a seat.
questions.explanation: While hazardous materials are being transported, shipping papers should either be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be clearly visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerC: Other items.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Hidden under the seat.
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.answerC: The destination.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Kept under the passenger’s seat.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerC: Made of cardboard.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerC: Straps.
questions.explanation: When loading or unloading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use hooks, or any other tools that could damage containers or packaging.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.answerC: Watch for signs of leakage.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: On low bridges:
questions.answerA: Height warnings must always be posted.
questions.answerB: Height warnings must be posted at least twice.
questions.answerC: Height warnings may be posted, but do not have to be.
questions.explanation: Height warnings are often, but not always, posted on low bridges. If you are unsure if you will be able to clear an overhead object, go slowly.

questions.question: What is a shut-off valve?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents air from escaping an air brake system
questions.answerC: An object connected to the spring brake system
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase the distance between you and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Avoid relying on tricks to help others pass.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely, you should increase your following distance, avoid making quick moves, and avoid relying on tricks (such as flashing your lights) to help other drivers pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing the tailgater to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If you don't pull the dolly out from beneath the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook:
questions.answerA: The tow bar may cause injury.
questions.answerC: The pintle hook may detach.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: When driving with trailers, you should:
questions.answerC: Accelerate by pushing the accelerator to the floor.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of tipping over when driving with a trailer, you should steer gently and smoothly. Avoid making sudden movements.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.answerC: Slippery roads
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: A truck should be parked:
questions.answerA: So that it must be backed up to leave the space.
questions.answerB: So that it can be pulled forward to leave the space.
questions.answerC: On the grass.
questions.explanation: Because you can't see everything behind you, backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. Choose parking spaces from which you can pull forward when you leave.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerC: Air lines.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Combination vehicles are usually:
questions.answerA: Easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: More difficult to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Driving combination vehicles requires more skill than driving single commercial vehicles. Combinations are generally longer, generally heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is better for training
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.answerC: An emergency brake system
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail for one of two reasons. Which of the following is one of those reasons?
questions.answerA: There is a loss of hydraulic pressure.
questions.answerC: The brakes get too cold.
questions.answerD: The brakes are used too much in one day.
questions.explanation: Most hydraulic brake failures occur for one of two reasons. A first likely cause of brake failure is that the brakes have been overused on a downgrade, causing them to fade. The second likely cause is that there has been a loss of hydraulic pressure in the braking system. Brakes kept in good condition will rarely fail, but you should know which steps to take in case they do.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.answerC: The brakes are fully operational.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: If hydraulic brakes fail, a driver can reduce their speed by:
questions.answerC: Finding a hill.
questions.answerD: Letting the truck run out of gas.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic bakes fail, shifting into a lower gear can help slow your vehicle down.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Steering wheel play of more than ____ can make steering difficult.
questions.answerC: 50 degrees
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: When starting an engine:
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.answerC: Coolant temperatures should decrease.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerC: Regardless of the weather.
questions.answerD: While minimizing the vehicle's fuel use.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerC: Stay in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Drive faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Not apply any brake.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: Which of the following indicates drowsy driving?
questions.answerA: Eyes going out of focus by themselves
questions.answerB: Having trouble keeping your head up
questions.answerC: Drifting from lane to lane
questions.explanation: Indicators of drowsiness while driving include your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, having trouble keeping your head up, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerC: Will not rollover.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer tends to swing around.
questions.answerC: The cab will swing, but the trailer will stay straight.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerC: Either lane
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.answerC: Air
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow the vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: During a trip, which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerC: Tires
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly monitor the instruments, gauges, meters, and mirrors. Check the tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: 75 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Spread out in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Cargo weight should be evenly distributed within a trailer to reduce the risk of a rollover. Do not place too much weight on one side of a trailer.

questions.question: When making a visual check of a coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Make sure the kingpin is polished.
questions.answerC: Look for mud on the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When performing a visual check of coupling devices, you should make sure there is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel. Ensure that the locking jaws are securely closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: What can happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerC: Proper steering may be impossible.
questions.explanation: Leaks in an exhaust system are extremely dangerous because they may allow toxic fumes into the cab or sleeper berth, endangering drivers and passengers.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.answerC: You should look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day because hazards become more difficult to see in the dark.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: The amount of liquid cargo than can be loaded into a tank depends on:
questions.answerC: The ability of the driver.
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, and legal weight limits. If you are loading a particularly dense liquid, make sure you do not exceed legal weight limits.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerC: Use only the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: Texting while driving a CMV is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if the text is work-related.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if there are fewer than 10 words in the text message.
questions.answerC: Encouraged because it is safer than talking on the phone.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a commercial motor vehicle is both illegal and dangerous. Manually entering text into or reading text from any electronic device is considered texting.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass vehicles if they aren’t driving the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Adjust driving to match the conditions.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Make sure to drive slowly and smoothly on slippery roads. Do not pass slower vehicles unless it is necessary to do so. Avoid frequently changing your speed under such conditions.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: In poor weather, many drivers:
questions.answerA: Like to drive in front of trucks.
questions.answerB: Like to drive to the sides of trucks.
questions.answerC: Like to follow trucks.
questions.explanation: In bad weather, many automobile drivers will follow large trucks too closely, particularly if visibility is poor.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for correctly labeling and marking them. The driver should make sure that the shipper properly labeled and marked the materials before beginning a trip.

questions.question: To avoid a crash:
questions.answerA: Braking is always the best option.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than braking.
questions.answerC: Drivers should leave 100 yards of distance between their vehicle and the next.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest response to a hazard on the road. You can almost always turn to avoid an obstacle faster than you can stop.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver doesn’t see you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn.
questions.answerD: Wait for the other driver to signal that it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Operating a combination vehicle usually requires ­­­­­____ operating a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.answerC: More skill than
questions.answerD: Exactly the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more skill to drive than single vehicles. Combination vehicles are usually longer and heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollovers.

questions.question: What could indicate that a shipment you are accepting contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Liquid surge occurs in:
questions.answerC: Tanks that have been emptied.
questions.explanation: Liquids may surge back and forth in tanks that have been partially filled. Tank drivers should be aware of how surge can affect the handling of their vehicles.

questions.question: Tanks have high centers of gravity, which means:
questions.answerA: They get very good gas mileage.
questions.answerB: They are easy to roll over.
questions.answerC: They are very stable.
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles have high centers of gravity, which makes them vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: Why do drivers have to inspect their vehicles?
questions.answerA: It is usually a company policy.
questions.answerB: It is usually a local ordinance.
questions.answerC: It is a federal and state law.
questions.answerD: It adds to the amount of time for which they will be paid.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before driving to ensure that they are safe to operate.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for most trucks.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most situations.
questions.answerC: Is required on newer trucks.
questions.explanation: Beginning between 1997 and 1999, most commercial vehicles, trailers, and dollies are required to be equipped with ABS.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: If feeling drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Safely leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the best thing to do is to stop and get some sleep. A driver trying to push on and finish a trip while fatigued is a major cause of fatal accidents.
