questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will usually continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerC: The trailer will likely swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer tends to swing around, potentially resulting in a trailer jackknife, if its wheels lock up.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of distraction?
questions.answerC: Obtuse
questions.explanation: Distractions that can affect safe driving can be classified as physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as talking with passenger), or both (such as talking on a hand-held phone).

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.answerC: Make turns more dangerous.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: After coupling, there should be ____ between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: A lot of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerC: Before you start moving downhill.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.answerC: Circle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerC: Emergency air line.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions are used:
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle run more smoothly.
questions.answerC: To get improved gas mileage.
questions.answerD: To make a vehicle less noisy.
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears. They are usually controlled by a selector knob on the gearshift lever.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: 3/4 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: If a tank is found to be leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive with their emergency flashers activated.
questions.answerC: Continue the trip and then inform someone about the leak.
questions.explanation: When inspecting any kind of tank, it is most important to check the tank for leaks. It is illegal to transport any gas or liquid in a leaking tank.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerC: 500 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: To avoid a crash:
questions.answerA: Braking is always the best option.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than braking.
questions.answerC: Drivers should leave 100 yards of distance between their vehicle and the next.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest response to a hazard on the road. You can almost always turn to avoid an obstacle faster than you can stop.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the passenger side of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Placed on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be kept as low to the ground as possible. Weight should not be placed primarily on one side of the trailer as this could make the trailer lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.answerC: Green ice.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: A surge occurs with which type of cargo?
questions.answerC: Gas
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles carrying liquid cargo are vulnerable to surge. Liquid surge is an occurrence in which a wave of liquid sloshes from one end or side of a tank to the other, causing dangerous effects on handling.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance of driving to:
questions.answerA: Recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.answerC: Polish the tire.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.answerC: Send someone else for help.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: When preparing to drive in the winter, be sure to check:
questions.answerC: The windshield wipers.
questions.explanation: Before driving during the winter, make sure to check your defrosting and heating equipment, coolant and antifreeze levels, wipers and washers, tire tread, tire chains, lights, reflectors, and exhaust system. Clear ice and snow from all windows, mirrors, hand holds, steps, deck plates, and radiator shutters. Make sure the winterfront is not closed too tightly.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.answerC: 4/32 of an inch
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are very far off course.
questions.answerC: You should pull up to reposition the vehicle as needed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, you should pull up to reposition your vehicle as needed.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerC: The engine should be running.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire has remained clean.
questions.answerC: Inflate the new tire.
questions.explanation: After changing a tire, you should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: Good drivers consistently look ____ seconds ahead of their vehicles.
questions.explanation: Most good drivers consistently look down the road 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Watching ahead of your vehicle will allow you to react to upcoming hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerC: Either lane
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have room for your vehicle to safely fit under an overhead object, you should slow down while approaching it. Seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.answerC: Continue to accelerate.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: The safety belt should:
questions.answerC: Be frayed.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should verify that the safety belt is securely mounted, adjusts, latches properly, and is not ripped or frayed.

questions.question: The line that passengers must stand behind is called:
questions.answerC: The rear line.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brakes?
questions.answerC: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: The minimum size of placards identifying hazardous materials is:
questions.answerC: Nine and three-quarter inches.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be at least 10 and three-quarter inches square.

questions.question: When stopped on the side of the road, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.answerC: Are exempt from traffic laws.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: A liver can process about ____ per hour.
questions.answerC: Three alcoholic drinks
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the higher your blood alcohol content (BAC) will become. The liver removes alcohol from a body at a fixed rate of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerC: Tire tread is too deep.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.answerC: You should look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: Once cargo is secured:
questions.answerA: You may complete an entire trip without checking it.
questions.answerB: You can drive at least eight hours without checking it.
questions.answerC: You should check it every three hours or 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If an Anti-Locking Braking System (ABS) is not working on a truck:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at low speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: Parts of an exhaust system should be:
questions.answerC: Fastened securely.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: Fueling with passengers on board:
questions.answerB: Should only be done if absolutely necessary.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern as long as the passengers stay inside the bus.
questions.answerD: Should be done to show the passengers that there is enough fuel to get to the next stop.
questions.explanation: You should not refuel a bus while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. In particular, never refuel a bus carrying passengers while inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch in the grooves on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Caring for the injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: What is aggressive driving?
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with some regard for other motorists’ safety
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner, without regard for the rights or safety of others.

questions.question: When pulling back into traffic after making a stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will allow you to merge.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap in traffic that is large enough to allow you to accelerate and merge.
questions.answerC: Allow a passenger to get out and direct traffic to allow you to merge.
questions.answerD: Continually sound your horn until other drivers allow you to merge.
questions.explanation: When driving a bus, be aware of how quickly it can accelerate and much space it takes up on the roadway. Always wait for a  gap in traffic that is large enough to accommodate your vehicle before you leave a stop.

questions.question: When a construction worker is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerC: Not drive in any lane.
questions.answerD: Wait to proceed until the construction is complete.
questions.explanation: In construction zones, do not exceed the posted safe sped limit. Slow down even more when workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: If a speed limit is posted, the posted speed:
questions.answerB: May be exceeded if passing another vehicle.
questions.answerC: May be exceeded if driving in a rural area.
questions.explanation: A maximum posted speed limit is the fastest a vehicle may travel under ideal circumstances. A driver should decrease their driving speed as conditions require. A driver should never exceed the legal speed limit.

questions.question: When checking power steering hoses during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Extra hose pieces available for repairs.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection on a vehicle with power steering, be sure to check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in a higher gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.answerC: Twice a week.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerC: Air brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Tractor protection valve
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: On newer vehicles, how do you put on the parking brake?
questions.answerA: Move a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Push in the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pull out the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerD: Pull up on the steering column.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The knob is pulled out to set the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle equipped with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Pull out the air brake knob.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, you should simply press the brake pedal down.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerC: Pulling a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: What tells you how much pressure is in your vehicle's air tanks?
questions.answerC: The tractor protection valve
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to neutral.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.answerC: Gasoline
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerC: A GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.explanation: In an air brake system with manually operated drains, the tanks should be drained at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.answerC: 3 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator is especially important:
questions.answerC: In dry weather.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: 75 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.answerC: Gravel.
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerC: After about a minute.
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a single vehicle with air brakes?
questions.answerC: 3 psi in one minute
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.answerC: Continue driving normally
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: When the spring brakes are activated in a vehicle with air brakes, you should never:
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, never push the brake pedal down when the spring brakes are activated. The combined force of the springs and the pressure of the air brakes could damage the brakes.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerC: 150 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerC: Liquid cleaners
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter an air tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from an air tank.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.answerC: Next to
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerC: GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.answerC: One third
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: It stops the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: It turns on the air compressor.
questions.answerC: It stores the compressed air.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the storage tanks. It stops pumping if the pressure in the tanks becomes too high, and begins pumping if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: 15 mph
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when drivers:
questions.answerC: Pay attention to the road.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver taking a turn at too high a speed. Be sure to take turns and curves safely and slowly.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.answerC: More difficult
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.answerC: Slippery roads
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.answerC: The trailer service brakes.
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.answerC: Pulling a trailer.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.answerC: Deactivated.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: All trailers made after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When coupling:
questions.answerA: You can assume all vehicles are the same.
questions.answerB: Be sure that you are coupling correctly.
questions.answerC: Cracks in the mounting are acceptable.
questions.explanation: Incorrect coupling and uncoupling of combination vehicles can have extremely dangerous consequences.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.answerC: Sound the horn.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.answerC: May be easier to steer during turns.
questions.explanation: Positioning the weight of a load on one side of a trailer may cause the trailer to lean to that side, increasing the risk of a rollover during turns and lane changes.

questions.question: How many air lines does a combination vehicle have?
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Steer in the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.answerC: Can cause a skid.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: If you cannot reverse your trailer in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerA: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.answerC: Back toward the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will allow you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerC: Will not rollover.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by a tractor.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: If you are backing and become unsure about your path of travel, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop and get out to look.
questions.answerC: Continue backing, but more slowly than before.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of your path while you are driving in reverse, you should stop, exit the vehicle, and recheck your path of travel.

questions.question: Pushing in the trailer air supply control will:
questions.answerC: Prevent the vehicle from skidding.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.answerC: No space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.answerC: Sound the horn.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.answerC: Prevent a skid.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: What does the tractor protection valve do?
questions.answerA: Protects the tractor from being stolen
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a leak
questions.answerD: Ensures oil adequately lubricates the engine
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.

questions.question: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor:
questions.answerA: At a 90-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerC: At a 30-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerD: At a 60-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: What is the tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve that keeps air in the brake system should a bad leak occur
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the trailer from being accidentally released
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the vehicle from going too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.answerC: More difficult
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance can present challenges when driving over:
questions.answerC: Overpasses.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Operating a combination vehicle usually requires ­­­­­____ operating a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.answerC: More skill than
questions.answerD: Exactly the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more skill to drive than single vehicles. Combination vehicles are usually longer and heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollovers.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.answerC: Are twice the width.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: If the trailer begins to skid, it is best to:
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel one way, then the other.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to help regain traction. Once the wheels grip the road again, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the path of the tractor.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerC: The vehicle will maintain steering.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is better for training
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.answerC: Unsafe to drive.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: Shut-off valves:
questions.answerA: Prevent air from escaping air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from entering air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Override vehicles that are out of control.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.
